Replace.Text: For this Age, gain +15% Science[icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] at the cost of -10% Culture[icon:YIELD_CULTURE]

For this Age, gain +15% Science[icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] at the cost of -10% Culture[icon:YIELD_CULTURE]
For this Age, gain +15% CULTURE[icon:YIELD_CULTURE] at the cost of -10% Science[icon:YIELD_Science]
Legend Unlock. +15% [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION]Production towards constructing Buildings and Wonders with Great Works slots.
Legend Unlock. +1 to the adjacencies of standard [icon:YIELD_GOLD]Gold, [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION]Production, and [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE]Science Buildings.

Augusta Ada King, Countess of Lovelace, (1815-1852) was born into a family of contrasts. She was the only legitimate child of the Romantic poet Lord Byron, who left England shortly after her birth and never saw her again. His dramatic, chaotic, and excessively creative persona was countered by that of his wife, Lady Byron, who was also an intellectual, but more inclined towards mathematics and the sciences. While he was wild and impulsive, she was rigid, strict, deeply religious, and heavily involved in education reform and abolitionism.

Ada was raised primarily by her maternal grandmother. Although her mother was not often present, she kept a sharp eye on her daughter and encouraged her interest in math and science – she feared that if Ada indulged in creativity like her father, she would follow in his destructive footsteps. Ada did share her mother’s academic nature, but she also inherited her father’s imagination. In one story often told about her childhood, Ada became fascinated with birds and determined to learn how to fly, a project that combined creative thinking with rigorous research on how wings work and what materials were best suited for human operation.

Thanks to her mother’s investment in her education, Ada was tutored by several prominent scholars of the day, including mathematician Augustus De Morgan and astronomer Mary Somerville. When Ada was 18, Somerville introduced her to Charles Babbage, whose work as an engineer and inventor led him to create the Difference Engine, now considered to be the first mechanical computer. She was immediately captivated by his invention and began to work closely with him. Between 1842 and 1843, she translated an article by Luigi Menabrea from Italian into English that examined Babbage’s next creation, the Analytical Engine. This machine was designed to solve mathematical problems fed through punch cards, but it was never fully built due to funding issues.

In her translation of Menabrea’s article, Ada included copious notes about the nature of the Analytical Engine and the possibilities its mechanics held. In particular, she speculated that the mathematical variables it processed could be treated as substitutes for more abstract concepts. The culmination of her additions is Note G, which presented a theoretical algorithm often considered to be the first computer program. Her contributions far outweighed both the length and insights of the original article, demonstrating not only her thorough understanding of how the machine worked, but also the breadth of her vision regarding what it could accomplish.

In 1835, at the age of 20, she married William, 8th Baron King, and they had three children. Along with mathematics, she maintained a strong interest in religion, mesmerism, and music, and kept herself up to date with the most recent scientific breakthroughs. She died of cancer at age 36.
To use and apply the language of science, we must fully appreciate, feel, seize the unseen.
Ada - a pleasure. Tell me, what are your thoughts on calculus?
Ada - a pleasure. Tell me, what are your thoughts on calculus?
Ada - a pleasure. Tell me, what are your thoughts on calculus?
The life-blood of this universe is not yours to drain. Begone, scoundrel!
You have lost your mind, and your head will soon follow.
In my fading footsteps, may mankind find a little of that brightness from Beyond.
Your insight into this matter is most remarkable.
Your variable has no place in my equations.

Cities receive +2 [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science per Age when you complete a Civic Mastery. This resets at the start of each age. Gain [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture equal to 50% of your total [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science per turn when you complete a Technology Mastery.

[LIST][LI]Cities receive +2[icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science per Age when you complete a Civic Mastery. This resets at the start of each age. [LI]Gain [icon:YIELD_CULTURE] Culture equal to 50% of your total [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE] Science per turn when you complete a Technology Mastery.[/LIST]
Likes the Leader with the most Masteries. Dislikes the one with the Least Masteries.

From childhood, Ada Lovelace inspected the world through a scientist’s eyes. Forging a path between intellectualism and imagination, she applied her mathematical mind to the 19th century’s most cutting-edge experiments. Working with mechanical computers, which made calculations using gears and punch cards, she designed the first computer program, establishing the field of computing over a century before technology caught up to her vision.
Gain 20 [icon:YIELD_SCIENCE]Science Per Age for every Science Building constructed.
Every time you research a Technology or Civic Mastery, the Capital gains [icon:YIELD_PRODUCTION]Production equal to 15% of its cost.

Contains a new Leader, Ada Lovelace.

Equations and crude illustrations detail Ada's thoughts, offering a glimpse into the chaotic workings of her mind. On paper, it's hard to tell if the model works — time is of the essence, if she wishes to make progress.
Keep iterating; the solution will come.
Source feedback from the community first.
Members of high society whisper as Ada takes a seat in their row. Rumor says she created a method to predict which horse wins the race. Others scoff, seeing it as nothing but luck.
Let them talk! Intrigue keeps the races fun.
Dispel the rumors and bet on a slow horse.
Neighbors argue about the role faith plays in the sciences. Is it not human nature to assign meaning to chaos? To understand how the Gods operate?
Faith is a tool no different from a calculator.
Faith creates as many questions as answers.
There is too much randomness in the world for it to be accidental.

Ada ties weights to her yarn so they’re taught against the warp. She interlaces several colors, weaving complex patterns as if writing intricate formulae. Connecting the concepts, she wonders if there’s a connection between the two.
Turn this experience into a lesson plan.
Sell the textiles made from the loom.
Drawn to her brilliance, a community of scientists and philosophers offer its services to Ada Lovelace.
After a few days sequestered in deliberation, the philosophers emerge with new and exciting theories that challenge Ada's own ideas.
Have 3 Points in the Great Library Legacy Path.
Shape the earth to their will.
Ada Lovelace's aides shape and fire clay to form bricks, thinking of the different people who will one day walk upon their work.
A scholar stumbles into Ada at the library. They apologize for the mess, citing the disorganized works strewn about.
An organized archive inspires an organized mind.
The scholar shelves freshly bound books, pleased with the spines tucked neatly into place.
Have 6 Points in the Great Library Legacy Path.
This mess is not worth cleaning.
Rapid growth prompts many to search for a new home. Explorers buzz with excitement over the new places they will see and things they will learn.
Supply the caravan with gifts and an envoy.
After days of traveling, the caravan stake their claim on land worthy of building upon.
Send them off with what they have.
As construction of the university ends, an architect takes note of of the temple nearby. They have heard that houses of worship often denounce the work of academics.
Let them bring persecution — it won't work.
The idea is to bridge the gap. Create understanding.
The binary nature of such a question is restrictive. Better to ask why.
A schoolchild raises his hand. He disagrees with a passage from his theology book, and wants to read something else. Ada peers over his shoulder, scanning the text.
Show the child how religion provides context.
Allow the child to pick something educational to read.
Ada smoothes out the top of a hospital bed, removing the last wrinkle. Folds in the fabric resemble a brain, reminding her of times when her own mind became a prisoner of it's own design.
The brain is seperate from the body; it doesn't tire so quickly.
A strong mind can overcome all.
Ada listens as a scientist and priest discuss what hidden forces shape the world, including the gods and the mystical. Conversation grows tense as their worldviews clash.
Faith can assign meaning and motivate our work.
It's the mystical that drives us to find answers.
The night sky twinkles faintly of stars and constellations for Ada to interpret.
She sees the Centaur — creative, pragmatic, and unforgettable.
She sees the Chisel, engraving her name in the cosmos forever.
The best and brightest in their fields endeavor on behalf of Ada, championing her values wherever they go.
It would be a waste not to utilize these specialists skills.
Finding work for the specialists proves easy. A niche field calls for experts, and the city has fostered many.
The effort it takes to find them work outweighs the benefits.
Buildings are not constructed just to be a leader's namesake. As a leader, Ada is many things... but uneducated is not one of them.
Ada's cities will continue to grow, guided by her steady and confident hand.
Have 5 Points in the Enlightenment Legacy Path.
The power of invocation could be a powerful remedy for ailments of the body and brain.
Encourage the people to have an open mind.
Data must be collected, but placebo or not, Ada's people are happier and healthier with prayer.
Change looms on the horizon. A shift in the status quo — murmors of dissent over religious teachings mix with fear of the unknown.
To quell fears and shut down naysayers, relics are put on display, becoming an anchor to ground the people.
Have 5 Points in the Toshakhana Legacy Path.
Advisors caution Ada that her designs are too ambitious and impossible to build. Progress is slow without her at the helm, but formulas don't write themselves.
Better to be behind than out of the race.
{1_reward} on Science Buildings but {2_reward} in Towns.
{1_reward} in Towns but {2_reward} on Science Buildings.
Ada taps the quill against her forehead, willing a breakthrough to spring forth. Electricity powers machines and provides light, but there must be more innovative ways to use it.
Design a device to examine the brain.
Design a device that stores electricity for later use.
Being both a mathematician and poet, Ada is often questioned for the paradox she is. Eager to show colleagues the inner workings of her mind, she comes up with a plan.
Host a writing workshop for other mathematicians.
Challenge artists to come up with inventions.
Smoke rises from ash where a thriving scientific community once stood. Those few who remain march to {1_Capital} with the last of their strength, and beg Ada Lovelace for succor.
Let them work the music halls.

After hours of translating complex engineering notes, Ada is confident she'll find a sponsor for this new prospect. With new avenues widening her reach, how hard can it be to build what has never been built?
Engineers abroad may be able to help with funding.
A network of scholars is sure to know someone with deep pockets.
A new class of sharp-minded women is ready to start the semester, and they look to Ada for a recommendation on what to study.
Won't Someone Think of the Antiquarians?
Ada has just sat down for tea when representatives from the Society of Antiquaries barge into her rooms. They bemoan the rapid pace of modernization, and insist more be done to preserve the past.
The lessons of history are invaluable.
Ambition is the driving force of humankind — where else is there to go but up? This is an opportunity to build something big.
The future of Ada's legacy is one rocket closer to the moon. What comes after that remains to be discovered.
Beneath the soil lie remnants of people long gone, whose stories and trinkets are waiting to be unearthed and shared with the world.
Now that the artifacts have been unearthed and preserved, they may now be studied and learned from.
Have 5 Points in the Geographic Society Legacy Path.
As Ada Lovelace, access a new Exploration Legacy Card:[n] +15% Science, -10% Culture

[B]Ada Lovelace[/B] was from the same continent as [B]Greece[/B].
[B]Ada Lovelace[/B] was from the same continent as [B]Rome[/B].
[B]Ada Lovelace's[/B] Britain was once ruled by [B]the Normans[/B].
[B]Ada Lovelace[/B] was from the same continent as [B]Russia[/B].
